QuickAccess_Tab_Perf_GameProfileExplaine:
Performance settings (like refresh rate, framerate limit, etc) can be adjusted for the system as a whole, or on a per-game basis.

If a title doesn’t have a game-specific performance profile (or this is toggled off), the default system settings will be used.
QuickAccess_Tab_Perf_AppRefreshRate_Expl:
Specify the maximum frames per second (FPS) the game is allowed to render. Users typically prefer framerate limits near (or slightly lower than) the game's average framerate.

Higher framerates typically produce smoother / lower-latency gameplay, at the expense of increased power usage.

Some games may have adverse effects when refresh rate limiting is enabled, including increased input lag or audio glitches. For these cases it is recommended to set the framerate limit to maximum.
QuickAccess_Tab_Perf_AppRefreshRate_Rest: A firmware update is required to use this feature.
QuickAccess_Tab_Perf_DisableFrameLimit_E:
Disabling the frame limit allows games to render as fast as hardware performance allows (potentially higher than the display refresh rate).

This setting may minimize frame latency for some games, but can potentially consume large amounts of power to render frames that will not reach the screen.

It is recommend to keep this setting disabled under normal usage to preserve battery life.
QuickAccess_Tab_Perf_GamescopeRefreshRat:
Specify the maximum refresh rate for the screen. Users typically prefer refresh rates near (or slightly lower than) the game's average framerate.

Higher refresh rates typically produce smoother / lower-latency gameplay by allowing the game to render at a higher framerate. However, a higher framerate will result in increased power usage.

Some games may have adverse effects when refresh rate switching is enabled, including increased input lag or audio glitches. For these cases it is recommended to set the refresh rate to the maximum allowed value.
MandatoryUpdate_Text:
Hello! You got one of the first Steam Deck OLED units, and we need to install some updates before you're ready to go.

This will take 7-8 minutes - it requires a couple reboots, and your screen will turn off for a minute in the middle. Hang tight and you'll be gaming in no time.

QuickAccess_Tab_Perf_LimitFrameRate_Warn: Current app misbehaves with FPS limit
QuickAccess_Tab_Perf_VariableResolutionD: Applies Variable Rate Shading to save power
QuickAccess_Tab_Perf_DynamicRefreshRateD: Switches the refresh rate of the screen to match FPS limit for a smoother output
QuickAccess_Tab_Perf_GPUClockControlDesc: Sets the GPU to a fixed clock
QuickAccess_Tab_Perf_TDPLimitEnabledDesc: Limits processor power for less total power
QuickAccess_Tab_Perf_FSRDescription: When the game is upscaled, sharpens image quality
QuickAccess_Tab_Perf_Overlay_Explainer:
Adjust this setting to control how much data is shown in the performance overlay.

The performance overlay provides realtime data about the current status of your device, including frames per second, power consumption, GPU and CPU usage and more. This data can be useful to determine how a settings change impacts performance and battery life.
QuickAccess_Tab_Perf_LimitFrameRate_Expl:
Change this value limit the maximum number of frames per second a game is allowed to render (framerate).

Setting a framerate limit can be useful to stabilize a game's framerate. When a game quickly oscillates between framerates it can make gameplay feel choppy. In this case using a framerate limit that is low enough to produce a non-oscillating framerate can produce a more enjoyable gameplay experience.

Limiting the framerate can also be useful to reduce power consumption.

Some games can have adverse interactions when a framerate limit is enabled, including increased input lag and audio glitches. For these cases it may be desireable to disable the framerate limit.
QuickAccess_Tab_Perf_FrameLimit_Explaine:
Adjust this setting to limit the maximum number of frames per second a game is allowed to render (framerate). This will automatically set the display’s refresh rate to a multiple of the framerate.

Limiting framerate can be useful for reducing power consumption, as lower framerates require less power. It’s also useful in cases where a game’s framerate is unstable and choppy. Using a limit that’s low enough to stabilize framerate can make for a more enjoyable gameplay experience.

Some games may exhibit issues when a framerate limit is enabled, including increased input lag and audio glitches. In these cases it’s probably better to disable the framerate limit.
QuickAccess_Tab_Perf_TDPLimit_Explainer_:
Adjust this value to limit the maximum amount of power %1$s is allowed to consume.

Lowering the TDP limit reduces the amount of work the system is allowed to do per second. This results in improved battery life, but will also reduce the system’s performance while playing games.

Adjust this value to limit the maximum amount of power this device is allowed to consume.

Lowering the TDP limit reduces the amount of work the system is allowed to do per second. This results in improved battery life, but will also reduce the system’s performance while playing games.
QuickAccess_Tab_Perf_GPUClockManual_Expl:
Adjust this value to set a fixed clock for the system’s GPU, which can be useful for stabilizing a game’s framerate.

Normally the GPU automatically adjusts clock frequency to balance battery consumption and performance. Some games have drastic transitions between low and high GPU usage, which sometimes hitch if the GPU does not ramp up the clocks fast enough. For these cases it can be useful to set a fixed clock to avoid a hitch due to an underclocked GPU.
QuickAccess_Tab_Perf_RefreshRate_Explain:
Change this value to set the display's refresh rate.

Adjusting the display's refresh rate can be useful to stabilize a game's framerate. When a game quickly oscillates between framerates it can make gameplay feel choppy. In this lowering the refresh rate to a value that is low enough to produce a non-oscillating framerate can lead to a more enjoyable gameplay experience.

Limiting the framerate can also be useful to reduce power consumption.
QuickAccess_Tab_Perf_EnableTearing_Expla:
This toggle allows a game to render at a different refresh rate than the display.

Synchronizing the game's render output with the display can introduce latency to the render pipeline. Enabling this setting can mitigate this latency, but can result in tearing artifacts during gameplay.

To take advantage of this setting, VSync must be disabled in the game's settings and the frame limit setting must be turned off.
QuickAccess_Tab_Perf_VariableResolution_:
Turning on half rate shading forcibly reduces the shading quality used by a game.

This can improve battery life and performance by reducing the amount of work a game needs to do to generate a new frame. This results in reduced visual quality for games.
QuickAccess_Tab_Perf_ScalingScaler_Expla: Change this value to modify how windows smaller than the current screen resolution get scaled to fit the screen.
QuickAccess_Tab_Perf_ScalingScaler_Auto_: Auto: Preserves aspect ratio, scales up to 2x
QuickAccess_Tab_Perf_ScalingScaler_Integ: Integer: Preserves pixel ratio (best for pixel art games)
QuickAccess_Tab_Perf_ScalingScaler_Fit_E: Fit: Preserves aspect ratio, scales up to fit the display
QuickAccess_Tab_Perf_ScalingScaler_Fill_: Fill: Fill the whole display, preserving aspect ratio (will result in clipping)
QuickAccess_Tab_Perf_ScalingScaler_Stret: Stretch: Fill the whole display without preserving aspect ratio
QuickAccess_Tab_Perf_ScalingFilter_Expla: Change this value to set the post processing filter applied when an application window is scaled:
QuickAccess_Tab_Perf_ScalingFilter_Neare: Pixel: Band limited nearest neighbour filter
QuickAccess_Tab_Perf_ScalingFilter_Sharp: Changing this value adjusts how sharp the resulting image will be. Adjust it according to visual preference.

Developer_SLS_Enabled_Description: Help improve SteamOS by sharing crash reports.
Developer_SLS_Enabled_Explainer:
Help improve SteamOS by sharing crash reports with the SteamOS development team.

This information will be used to help improve the reliability and compatibility of SteamOS.

You can configure the categories of data that will be shared. For more details on what data is included in each category please refer to the individual category toggles.
Developer_SLS_Minidump_Enabled_Explainer:
This report will be generated when an application crashes. This data will be used to help improve application compatibility and reliability with SteamOS.

The report contains a minidump of the crash with process heap collection disabled. The minidump will contain the runtime stack for each thread at the time of the crash, thread contexts including CPU register values, metadata about the CPU architecture and the executable name and path.
Developer_SLS_Kdump_Enabled_Explainer:
This report will be generated when the kernel encounters a fatal error. This data will be used to help improve general system stability for SteamOS.

The report contains a memory dump of the kernel when the crash happened and the kernel logs.
Developer_SLS_GPU_Enabled_Explainer:
This report will be generated when the system's GPU encounters a fatal error.

The report includes information reported by the GPU driver regarding the state of the graphics hardware when the error occurred. This may include information about the offending GPU command that caused the crash (if it could be identified), and the application that submitted said command.
Developer_SLS_Journal_Enabled_Explainer:
Share logs from critical system processes alongside a crash report. This supplementary information can provide the necessary context to help identify and resolve the root cause of a crash.

This report includes logs for the system update services, the boot management services, steamos management services, the settings management service and the steam crash collection service.
Developer_SLS_SystemInfo_Enabled_Explain:
This report contains information about the system state. This supplementary information can provide the necessary context to help identify bugs that only happen on certain hardware configurations.

This report includes RAM and VRAM size, SteamOS branch, hardware revision information, BIOS information, developer mode status, connected USB peripheral details (VID/PID/Manufacturer ID), external display information, connected audio device information, a list of connected bluetooth devices, filesystem and partition layout information, battery health and network interface details (excluding MAC and IP address details).
Developer_SLS_Devcoredump_Enabled_Explai:
This report will be generated when a driver encounters an unrecoverable error.

The report includes information reported by the kernel and driver regarding the state of the system when the error occurred. This may include detailed information from the driver that crashed, kernel logs, kernel stack traces and memory information.

ControllerConfigurator_Interstitial_Intr: Steam Input
To allow you to play any game, even if it doesn't support game controllers, your Deck uses <2>Steam Input</2>, a system that translates your physical inputs into commands for the game.

Controller configuration for your <1></1> uses <2>Steam Input</2>, a system that translates your physical inputs into commands for the game. This allows you to play any game, even if it wasn't designed for your particular controller or doesn't support gamepads.
<1>Commands</1> can be any kind of input that games use - a B button on a gamepad, the Enter key, a left mouse button click, and so on.
Each game's Controller Layout contains a list of all the physical parts of your controller, and what commands are assigned to them.
Customizing is as simple as selecting a physical input, and your desired command.
Deck Verified games always have fully working Controller Layouts, so you can just fire them up and start playing.
By default, they may not use the extra physical inputs the Deck has over standard gamepads, but the <1>Quick Settings</1> section makes it easy to assign commands for those.
By default, they may not use the extra physical inputs the Deck has over standard gamepads, but the <1>Quick Settings</1> section makes it easy to assign commands for those.
ControllerConfigurator_Interstitial_NonV: When playing non-verified games from your library, you may need to adjust your controller layout in order to make your game play better with your device’s controls.
Our default templates work for most games, but otherwise we always suggest checking the game's Community Layouts to see if another player has published a custom layout.
These games may ask you to press keys or buttons. In those cases, you’ll need to assign those commands to your device’s physical controls.
Even when the game asks you to press a button that your device has, you will need to assign a matching command.
Even when the game asks you to press a button that the <1></1> has, you will need to assign a matching command.
Even when the game asks you to press a button that the Deck has, your layout may have a different command assigned to that physical button.
Even when the game asks you to press a button that the <1></1> has, your layout may have a different command assigned to that physical button.
It's often a good technique to find the in-game control settings, which will contain a list of all the commands the game expects.
And then assign each of them to one of the Deck's physical inputs.
But remember to always check the Community Layouts first - some other player has probably done this already.
ControllerConfigurator_Interstitial_Gyro: The gyro allows you to move the Deck itself to control a game. This can be very useful for fine control of a first or third person camera.
The gyro allows you to move the gamepad itself to control a game. This can be very useful for fine control of a first or third person camera.

By default, the gyro only sends input to the game when you're touching the <1>Right Joystick</1> or <2>Right Trackpad</2>. It's easy to change this behavior in the gyro settings, but we've found it to work well.
By default, the gyro only sends input to the game when you're touching the <1>Right Trackpad</1>. It's easy to change this behavior in the gyro settings, but we've found it to work well.

By default, the gyro always sends input to the game. It's easy to change this behavior in the gyro settings and depending on the game you might want to use a button to turn off the gyro in order to reposition controller without affecting your aim.

ControllerConfigurator_Interstitial_Intr: This game has native support for <1>Steam Input</1>, the system Steam uses to translate your physical inputs. With native support, your layout will show Game Actions instead of generic commands.
These games will often contain <1>Action Sets</1> - different control schemes that are used during different parts of the game.
This means you'll be able to fully customize every part of the game to suit your preferences, but only if you choose to. The default layout provided by the game's developer will just work.
Space
Jump
Standard
Native Support

Many games have different control schemes for different parts of the game. You might have one control scheme for walking around on foot, another for driving a vehicle, and yet another when viewing a fullscreen map of the game world.

Games that support controllers will usually handle switching between these control schemes for you. But if you're playing a game that wasn't built with controllers in mind, or one that doesn't support controller customization to the level you'd like, you can use <1>Action Sets</1> to do it yourself.

Many games utilize unique control schemes during different scenarios within a game. Within Steam Input we call these Action Sets. For games built without controller support in mind, you may create your own custom Action Sets and switch between them in-game.
Changing which set is active is a command you can assign to any physical input.
Action Sets may also be <1>Layers</1>, which are smaller layouts layered over the top of the Action Set, often only changing the way a single physical input is translated.
For example, some games automatically lower your sensitivity when you zoom in to aim a weapon. For games that don't do it, you could use a Layer to reproduce the behavior.
First, create a Layer named 'While Aiming', and set it to lower sensitivity. Then add these commands to the Left Trigger:
With this setup, whenever you pulled the Left Trigger to aim, your sensitivity would automatically be lowered by the While Aiming Layer.

The "Dots Per 360°" setting determines how many pixels that is, so this action must be used in conjuction with Gyro to Mouse or FlickStick modes.

Tip: to correctly tune the "Dots Per 360°" setting per game, set the "Spin Angle" to 360°.

 If you're not facing your initial direction after the spin, adjust the "Dots Per 360°" setting from the Controller Quick Settings Page and repeat the process until you get an accurate 360°.

ControllerBinding_ModeDropDown_Dpad_Desc: This input will act as a D-pad.  D-Pad's are a 4 way directional input that is digital (on or off) in nature.  Any type of button can be assigned, but XInput buttons will only work with XInput Gamepad compatible games.
ControllerBinding_RequiresClick_Descript: If set, the trackpad must be clicked to operate.  If not set, simply touching will activate the D-Pad.
ControllerBinding_RequiresClick_On_Descr: The trackpad will only send commands when clicked.
ControllerBinding_RequiresClick_Off_Desc: The trackpad will send commands on touch.
ControllerBinding_DPadLayout_Description: This option selects the type of DPad emulation.
ControllerBinding_DPadLayout_RadialNoOve: A four way pie shaped layout with diagonals that only activate the single nearest directional command.
ControllerBinding_DPadLayout_RadialWithO: A pie shaped layout with diagonals that activate both directional commands.
ControllerBinding_DPadLayout_AnalogEmula: The directional commands are sent to the game in pulses to simulate an analog stick.
ControllerBinding_DPadLayout_CrossGate_D: A cross-shaped pad layout that prioritizes horizontal and vertical movement over the diagonals.
ControllerBinding_DpadClick_Description: This command will be performed when you click the pad/stick. If the 'Requires Click' option is also set, clicking a pad direction will send the corresponding direction command as well as this command to the game.
ControllerBinding_DpadTouch_Description: This command will be performed when you touch the pad/stick.
ControllerBinding_OverlapRegion_Descript: Overlap Region defines how much space in the diagonals applies to both directions.  At it's lowest setting, overlap is nearly removed, acting almost like a 4-way control, at its highest, overlap is almost always applied unless precisely on a cardinal direction.

ControllerBinding_GyroTo2DConversionStyl: Turn the controller around its own vertical axis for horizontal output. Tilt the controller up and down around its own lateral axis for vertical output. (Local Space Preset)
Lean the controller around its forward axis for horizontal output. Tilt the controller up and down around its own lateral axis for vertical output. (Local Space Preset)
Yaw + Roll adds the Lean and Turn together for horizontal output. Tilting the controller up and down around its own lateral axis still moves the mouse up and down. (Local Space Preset)

Local Space is similar to Yaw + Roll, but gives full control over the pitch angle of the principle axis. You can also adjust the contribution of the complementary axis (which is at 90 degrees to the principle axis).
Player Space uses Yaw + Roll around the gravity axis for horizontal output, and Local Pitch for vertical output.
World Space uses all rotation around the gravity axis for horizontal output, and World Pitch for vertical output, but does not move vertically when the controller is tilted on its side
Acts similar to a laser pointer. Great for cursor control or Light Gun games on a stand-alone controller.

ControllerBinding_CurveExponent_joystick: Stick Response Curve
ControllerBinding_CustomCurveExponent_jo: Changing this slider adjusts the output response curve for the joystick.
ControllerBinding_CurveExponent_joystick: This determines the mapping of analog input to output.  By default a linear 1:1 mapping is used.  This curve can altered so there is more or less room for fine controls.
Response Curve - Linear
A Linear response curve maps the input directly to the output in a 1:1 fashion.  At 50% deflection, 50% output will be sent.
Response Curve - Aggressive
An aggressive response curve gets to 100% output faster.  This gives less of a slow range and more quickly hits the upper range of output, with faster response.
Response Curve - Relaxed
A relaxed response curve gets to 100% output slower.  There is slightly more slow range where fine control can be used and the upper range is pushed further towards the edges.
Response Curve - Wide

A wide response curve gets to 100% output much slower than default.  There is a wide range of low values which ramps up quickly at the outer edges.  This allows for a wide amount of small values in the inner range while ramping to full at the outside.
Response Curve - Extra Wide
An extra wide response curve provides an large range of lower values over a wide band, only reaching 100% at the extremes.
Response Curve - Custom Curve
A Custom Curve can be defined using the response curve slider.
ControllerBinding_AccelerationStyle_Joys: Apply the response curve Per Axis, or based on the Distance from the Deadzone.
The response curve is applied separately to each axis. The output distance of the stick will vary based on the direction it is pushed.
The response curve is applied using the distance of the stick from the deadzone. Output distance in all directions will be equal.
ControllerBinding_DeadZoneInnerRadius_jo: Joystick events won't be sent if within this deadzone.  The slider is a radius of the deadzone, with fully to the left as no deadzone and fully right as the entire radius being deadzone.  Full analog output values are mapped to the zone between the inner and outer deadzone.  Extending out the inner deadzone will allow more area in the deadzone shape where no input is sent.
ControllerBinding_DeadZoneOuterRadius_jo: Joystick events will reach maximum upon hitting the outer deadzone.  The slider can be visualized as extending a radius from the center outward.  Full analog output values are mapped to the zone between the inner and outer deadzone.  Pulling in the outer deadzone will cause output to reach its full amount faster.
ControllerBinding_DeadZoneShape_joystick: Deadzones can take on different shapes to better match gameplay.  For example, a cross shaped deadzone is often best for movement where holding primarily forward has the side movement within the deadzone so movement doesn't drift for a less than 100% perfect alignment.

The cross shaped deadzone treats each axis separately with the inner deadzone being a band along that axis.  This creates a + shaped cross of deadzone along the axis.  This is often best for navigation where holding primarily in a single direction won't cause drift for a less that 100% perfect alignment.

A simple circle shaped deadzone.  Input in between the inner and outer deadzones is mapped to its relative distance between the two.  Any input inside the inner deadzone is not sent, while outside the outer is fully on in that direction.

The square deadzone uses a cross for determining the inner deadzone, but also maps the output from a circle into a square.  This makes output in the diagonals approach their maximum value more quickly.
ControllerBinding_AntiDeadZone_joystick_: Most games apply their own deadzones to controller output. If the control feels 'mushy' with a physical area of movement where no output is seen in game, it is likely caused by the game's deadzone. You can remove this using the Anti-Deadzone setting. This subtracts away the deadzone, and provides finer grain control within the remaining section.  The higher the slider, the more is added to the smallest output value.  Note that if all deadzone is removed entirely, all positions will cause input. You can use Anti-DeadZone Buffer to allow for a small area where no input will be sent, even if the anti-deadzone is larger than the deadzone of the game.
ControllerBinding_AntiDeadZoneBuffer_joy: If an anti-deadzone has been applied, there may be no remaining actual deadzone as applied by the game, so touching anywhere will actively cause movement.  To allow for a safe buffer area where no input will be sent, the anti-deadzone buffer acts as the new deadzone for the control.  It can be visualized as a radius from the center of the pad, within which no input will be sent.
ControllerBinding_InvertX_joystick_move_: If set, moving left will move the joystick right, while moving right will move the joystick left.  Note that game settings often have this same setting, so you need to ensure they don't cancel each other out.

If set, moving left will move the joystick right, while moving right will move the joystick left.  Note that game settings often have this same setting, so you need to ensure they don't cancel each other out.
The joystick Horizontal axis will act normally, with left movement on the pad corresponding to left movement of the joystick.
ControllerBinding_InvertY_joystick_move_: If set, moving up on the pad will move the joystick down, while moving down on the pad will move the joystick up.  Note that game settings often have this same setting, so you need to ensure they don't cancel each other out.
ControllerBinding_Rotation_joystick_move: Rotates the output to the joystick, such that pushing the physical stick "North" results in an output of "East", when set to 90°
ControllerBinding_InvertY_joystick_move_: If set, moving up on the pad will move the joystick down, while moving down on the pad will move the joystick up.  Note that game settings often have this same setting, so you need to ensure they don't cancel each other out.
The joystick vertical axis will act normally, with up movement on the pad corresponding to up movement of the joystick.
ControllerBinding_OutputAxis_joystick_mo: Output can be limited to a single axis if desired.  For example - steering with the Gyro in a racing game where you don't want to also scroll through vertical menus.
Output will be sent normally to both horizontal and vertical axis.
Output will be sent only to the vertical axis.
Output will be sent only to the horizontal axis.
ControllerBinding_GyroButtonInvert_joyst: The gyro input button behavior can be flipped.  If set to off, gyro will turn off when the button is pressed.
If set, the device's gyro will turn on when the button is pressed.
If set, the device's gyro will turn off when the button is pressed.
If set, the device's gyro will toggle its state each time the button is pressed.
ControllerBinding_MouseSensitivity_joyst: Sensitivity of the mouse cursor when the virtual joystick's output is set to Mouse.
ControllerBinding_HorizontalSensitivity_: Scale the horizontal sensitivity.  This will change the motion of the horizontal axis relative to the vertical.
ControllerBinding_VerticalSensitivity_jo: Scale the vertical sensitivity. This will change the motion of the vertical axis relative to the horizontal.
ControllerBinding_TrackPadToCameraAngles: This sets the number of degrees the camera will turn when the trackpad is swiped from one edge to the other (when acceleration is disabled).

A full swipe will generate 360° of rotation (when at 360° sensitivity). The Dots Per 360° value will convert the angles to mouse pixels. This value is shared with all other Dots Per 360° modes (in this Action Set). Tuning Tip: temporarily bind a button to the "Turn Camera 360°" action in the Mouse Actions tab to help calibrate the Gyro's real world angles with in-game angles.
ControllerBinding_GyroNeutralAngle_joyst: This is the tilt angle for a centering the joystick's Y axis output. By changing this setting you can alter the neutral centered angle to tilt forward or backward to your preference.  0° Positions the neutral tilt angle at the horizon in front of you. 90° places the neutral tilt angle straight up, toward the sky. Note that for uses like a steering wheel, it is recommended to disable the vertical portion entirely and just use the Horizontal Axis, where this angle will not come into play.
ControllerBinding_GyroLockExtents_joysti: When set, if the pad is rotated past outer edge, it will lock to that edge.  If not set, it may flip to the opposite side when crossing this outer edge.  If you experience problems with the controller locking up over time, you may want to disable this option.

When set, if the pad is rotated past outer deadzone, it will lock to that edge until rotated past 180 degrees.  If not set, it may begin to rotate in the opposite direction as it approaches 180 degrees of rotation.  If you experience problems with the controller locking up over time, disable this option.

When set, if the pad is rotated past outer deadzone, it will lock to that edge until rotated past 180 degrees.  If not set, it may begin to rotate in the opposite direction as it approaches 180 degrees of rotation.  If you experience problems with the controller locking up over time, disable this option.
ControllerBinding_ModeDropDown_Joystick_: This input controls a mouse with a joystick.  This is intended for using a joystick with mouse based applications.  As the output is a mouse, the application must support mouse based output.
ControllerBinding_OutputJoystick_joystic: Output Joystick
When sending analog joystick commands to the game, should those commands be a left or right joystick as seen by the game?
Output Joystick - Left
When sending analog joystick commands to the game, send a left analog joystick.
Output Joystick - Right
When sending analog joystick commands to the game, send a right analog joystick.
Output Absolute Mouse
Directly map the virtual joystick position to the full screen. Mouse Region mode provides the same functionality but has more options for the active area.
Output Relative Mouse
Steer the mouse cursor using the virtual joystick.
ControllerBinding_AdaptiveCentering_joys: Adaptive Centering treats the first touched position on the trackpad as the new 'center' of the joystick, where dragging out from that point will move the joystick around.  This allows for the thumb to be placed off-center without causing accidental motions.

Adaptive Centering treats the first touched position on the trackpad as the new 'center' of the joystick, where dragging out from that point will move the joystick around.  This allows for the thumb to be placed off-center without causing accidental motions.

The trackpad treats the center of the pad as the center of a joystick, while touching areas outside of the center is equivalent to deflecting the stick to that location as if it were a physical stick.
ControllerBinding_HapticIntensity_joysti: This sets the intensity of the haptics.
Do not use haptics for this mode.
ControllerBinding_Click_joystick_mouse_D: This command will be performed when you click the stick.
ControllerBinding_EdgeBindingRadius_joys: When outside this radius on the Joystick, the assigned button or key will be sent.  For example, the 'Run' or 'Sprint' button could be assigned when holding at the edge.  The slider can be visualized as extending a radius from the center outward, with the point being where the outer ring begins.
ControllerBinding_EdgeBinding_joystick_m: When outside the specified radius on the Joystick, the assigned button or key will be sent.  For example, the 'Run' or 'Sprint' button could be assigned when holding at the edge.
ControllerBinding_EdgeBindingInvert_joys: If set, the command will be sent when inside the radius instead of outside.  For example, 'Walk' or 'Sneak' could be sent when inside a certain zone.
The assigned button will be sent if inside the specified Outer Ring Command Radius. For example, 'Walk' or 'Sneak' could be sent when inside a certain zone.
The assigned button will be sent if outside the specified Outer Ring Command Radius. For example, 'Run' or 'Sprint' could be sent when outside a certain zone.
ControllerBinding_CurveExponent_joystick: Stick Response Curve
ControllerBinding_CustomCurveExponent_jo: Changing this slider adjusts the output response curve for the joystick.
ControllerBinding_CurveExponent_joystick: This determines the mapping of analog input to output.  By default a linear 1:1 mapping is used.  This curve can altered so there is more or less room for fine controls.
Response Curve - Linear
A Linear response curve maps the input directly to the output in a 1:1 fashion.  At 50% deflection, 50% output will be sent.
Response Curve - Aggressive
An aggressive response curve gets to 100% output faster.  This gives less of a slow range and more quickly hits the upper range of output, with faster response.
Response Curve - Relaxed
A relaxed response curve gets to 100% output slower.  There is slightly more slow range where fine control can be used and the upper range is pushed further towards the edges.
Response Curve - Wide

A wide response curve gets to 100% output much slower that default.  There is a wide range of low values which ramps up quickly at the outer edges.  This allows for a wide amount of small values in the inner range while ramping to full at the outside.
Response Curve - Extra Wide
An extra wide response curve provides an large range of lower values over a wide band, only reaching 100% at the extremes.
Response Curve - Custom Curve
A Custom Curve can be defined using the response curve slider.
ControllerBinding_DeadZoneInnerRadius_jo: Joystick events won't be sent if within this deadzone.  The slider is a radius of the deadzone, with fully to the left as no deadzone and fully right as the entire radius being deadzone.  Full analog output values are mapped to the zone between the inner and outer deadzone.  Extending out the inner deadzone will allow more area in the deadzone shape where no input is sent.
ControllerBinding_DeadZoneOuterRadius_jo: Joystick events will reach maximum upon hitting the outer deadzone.  The slider can be visualized as extending a radius from the center outward.  Full analog output values are mapped to the zone between the inner and outer deadzone.  Pulling in the outer deadzone will cause output to reach its full amount faster.
ControllerBinding_DeadZoneShape_joystick: Deadzones can take on different shapes to better match gameplay.  For example, a cross shaped deadzone is often best for movement where holding primarily forward has the side movement within the deadzone so movement doesn't drift for a less that 100% perfect alignment.

The cross shaped deadzone treats each axis separately with the inner deadzone being a band along that axis.  This creates a + shaped cross of deadzone along the axis.  This is often best for navigation where holding primarily in a single direction won't cause drift for a less than 100% perfect alignment.

A simple circle shaped deadzone.  Input in between the inner and outer deadzones is mapped to its relative distance between the two.  Any input inside the inner deadzone is not sent, while outside the outer is fully on in that direction.

The square deadzone uses a cross for determining the inner deadzone, but also maps the output from a circle into a square.  This makes output in the diagonals approach their maximum value more quickly.
ControllerBinding_AntiDeadZone_joystick_: Most games apply their own deadzones to controller output. If the control feels 'mushy' with a physical area of movement where no output is seen in game, it is likely caused by the game's deadzone. You can remove this using the Anti-Deadzone setting. This subtracts away the deadzone, and provides finer grain control within the remaining section.  The higher the slider, the more is added to the smallest output value.  Note that if all deadzone is removed entirely, all positions will cause input. You can use Anti-DeadZone Buffer to allow for a small area where no input will be sent, even if the anti-deadzone is larger than the deadzone of the game.
ControllerBinding_AntiDeadZoneBuffer_joy: If an anti-deadzone has been applied, there may be no remaining actual deadzone as applied by the game, so touching anywhere will actively cause movement.  To allow for a safe buffer area where no input will be sent, the anti-deadzone buffer acts as the new deadzone for the control.  It can be visualized as a radius from the center of the pad, within which no input will be sent.
ControllerBinding_InvertX_joystick_mouse: If set, moving left will move the joystick right, while moving right will move the joystick left.  Note that game settings often have this same setting, so you need to ensure they don't cancel each other out.

If set, moving left will move the joystick right, while moving right will move the joystick left.  Note that game settings often have this same setting, so you need to ensure they don't cancel each other out.
The joystick Horizontal axis will act normally, with left movement on the pad corresponding to left movement of the joystick.
ControllerBinding_InvertY_joystick_mouse: If set, moving up on the pad will move the joystick down, while moving down on the pad will move the joystick up.  Note that game settings often have this same setting, so you need to ensure they don't cancel each other out.
ControllerBinding_Rotation_joystick_mous: Rotates the output to the mouse, such that pushing the joystick "North" results in a mouse output "East", when set to 90°
ControllerBinding_InvertY_joystick_mouse: If set, moving up on the pad will move the joystick down, while moving down on the pad will move the joystick up.  Note that game settings often have this same setting, so you need to ensure they don't cancel each other out.
The joystick vertical axis will act normally, with up movement on the pad corresponding to up movement of the joystick.
ControllerBinding_OutputAxis_joystick_mo: Output can be limited to a single axis if desired.  For example - steering with the Gyro in a racing game where you don't want to also scroll through vertical menus.
Output will be sent normally to both horizontal and vertical axis.
Output will be sent only to the vertical axis.
Output will be sent only to the horizontal axis.
ControllerBinding_GyroButtonInvert_joyst: The gyro input button behavior can be flipped.  If set to off, gyro will turn off when the button is pressed.
If set, the device's gyro will turn on when the button is pressed.
If set, the device's gyro will turn off when the button is pressed.
If set, the device's gyro will toggle its state each time the button is pressed.
ControllerBinding_MouseSensitivity_joyst: Sensitivity of the mouse cursor when the virtual joystick's output is set to Mouse.
ControllerBinding_JoystickToCameraAngles: Sensitivity of the stick - how many camera degrees per second the camera will turn when fully deflected.
Joystick Angles to Mouse Pixels (Dots Per 360°)

At full deflection, the joystick will generate 360° of rotation over 1 second (when at 360° sensitivity). The Dots Per 360° value will convert the angles to mouse pixels. This value is shared with all other Dots Per 360° modes (in this Action Set). Tuning Tip: temporarily bind a button to the "Turn Camera 360°" action in the Mouse Actions tab to help calibrate the Gyro's real world angles with in-game angles.
ControllerBinding_DeadZonePrecisionJoyst: This will allow for finer grained control when making very small movements.  This must be tied with the Minimum Joystick X/Y Output Value to tune in to what a game expects for a small Joystick Value.  If Joystick X or Y Output Value is too high when combined with this setting, movement will be jittery even when not moving.  If it is too low, small movments will be missed entirely or very sluggish.  In combination with those settings, tune this value up to allow for very fine movements or down to reduce noise when trying to hold still.
ControllerBinding_CustomCurveExponent_mo: Games will sometimes have varying response curves for their joystick input.  For best Mouse-Like Joystick response, linear response is the most 1:1.  This setting can be altered to try to compensate for a game's built in response curve.  Generally this setting should be used as a last resort, but can be slid to the right to compensate for what feels like unwanted acceleration or poor initial response or slid to the left to compensate for inverted acceleration.
ControllerBinding_ModeDropDown_SingleBut: This input will act as a single button with commands for both touch and click events.
ControllerBinding_SingleButtonClick_Desc: This command will be sent when the pad is clicked.
ControllerBinding_SingleButtonTouch_Desc: This command will be sent when the pad is touched.
ControllerBinding_ModeDropDown_Camera_De: This input will operate as a joystick optimized for controlling a first or third person camera.  Joystick will only work with XInput compatible gamepad games.
ControllerBinding_OutputJoystickCameraMo: When sending analog joystick commands to the game, should those commands be a left or right joystick as seen by the game?

When sending analog joystick commands to the game, send a right analog joystick.
Directly map the virtual joystick position to the full screen. Mouse Region mode provides the same functionality but has more options for the active area.

ControllerBinding_AbsMouseMouseSensitivi: Sensitivity of the mouse cursor when the virtual joystick's output is set to Mouse.
ControllerBinding_ModeDropDown_AbsoluteM: This input will operate as a mouse.  It will control any mouse based interface such as a cursor or in-game camera.
ControllerBinding_AbsMouseClick_Descript: This command will be performed when you click the pad.
ControllerBinding_AbsMouseGyroLeft_Descr: This command will be performed when you lean the controller to the left.
ControllerBinding_AbsMouseGyroRight_Desc: This command will be performed when you lean the controller to the right.
ControllerBinding_Trackball_Description: Trackball mode makes the pad act like a trackball instead of a mouse.  It will have momentum and friction, allowing you to flick it like a trackball.
ControllerBinding_Trackball_On_Descripti: The mouse will move like a trackball.  It will have momentum and friction and can be flicked like a trackball.
ControllerBinding_Trackball_Off_Descript: The mouse will move like a normal mouse.  It will have not have momentum or friction.
ControllerBinding_Sensitivity_Descriptio: Sets the sensitivity of this control.  For the smoothest results, lowering in-game sensitivity while raising this hardware sensitivity will provide the game with more precision to work with.
ControllerBinding_Sensitivity2DScroll_De: Sets the sensitivity of this control. Higher sensitivity means less travel before the command fires
ControllerBinding_SensitivityTouchMenu_D: Sensitivity for the movement of the cursor within the Touch Menu.
ControllerBinding_RotationAbsMouse_Descr: Rotation is the horizon line of mouse movement.  Swiping your thumb over the trackpad may result in a slighly canted movement.  You can align this rotation to match your natural movements, so that a quick swipe results in a perfectly horizontal mouse movement.
ControllerBinding_Rotation2DScroll_Descr: Rotation is the horizon line of mouse movement.  Swiping your thumb over the trackpad may result in a slighly canted movement.  You can align this rotation to match your natural movements, so that a quick swipe results in a perfectly horizontal mouse movement.
ControllerBinding_RotationFlickStick_Des: Rotate the FlickStick inputs: This can be useful if an initial forward Flick consistently rotates you to one side of your expected direction.
ControllerBinding_OutputAxisFlickStick_D: Output the FlickStick to Horizontal (typical use) or vertical.
ControllerBinding_EdgeBindingRadiusFlick: Moving the Joystick past this radius will trigger the 'Outer Ring Command' (assigned on the Joystick settings menu).
ControllerBinding_GyroEnableButton_Descr: Selected buttons will Enable/Suppress/Toggle the Gyro. The Gyro will always be on if no buttons are selected.
ControllerBinding_GyroConfigurationModeS: Choose which buttons should Enable Gyro control.
Choose which buttons should Suppress Gyro control.
Choose which buttons should Toggle Gyro control.
ControllerBinding_GyroEnableButtonBehavi: Choose whether the selected buttons Enable, Suppress, or Toggle the gyro output.
ControllerBinding_GyroEnableButtonRequir: If you have multiple Gyro Buttons, choose whether they must "All" be pressed, or if "Any" can be pressed to Enable/Suppress/Toggle the gyro.
ControllerBinding_GyroButtonHapticEffect: Choose to have a haptic effect when the Gyro becomes enabled, disabled, or both. Uses Haptic Intensity to determine its strength.
ControllerBinding_GyroButtonOnOffHapticI: Choose how strong the effect of the Gyro Activation Haptic Effect should be.
ControllerBinding_GyroMultiselectToggle_: Turn this on to pick multiple Gyro Activation Buttons instead of just one.
ControllerBinding_GyroVerticalHorizontal: Reduce vertical sensitivity by moving the slider to the left, or reduce horizontal sensitivity by moving the slider to the right. At 0% output is a 1:1 Horizontal to Vertical ratio.
ControllerBinding_GyroSpeedDeadzone_Desc: The minimum amount of speed that the gyro must be moved before there is a reaction on screen. This is useful to combat hand shake, or natural bounce-back after a flick. Rotation output lost to the deadzone will be recovered when moving the controller at high speeds.
ControllerBinding_GyroPrecisionSpeed_Des: When rotating the controller below this speed, sensitivity is reduced relative to the speed. This makes smaller motions even smaller in game. This may be preferable to a deadzone for adept users. Rotation output lost to the precision filter will be recovered when moving the controller at high speeds.
ControllerBinding_GyroAnglesToPixels: Gyro Angles to Mouse Pixels (Dots Per 360°)
ControllerBinding_GyroAnglesToPixels_Des: For Natural Angles Calibration. One full 360° turn of the gyro will generate this many mouse pixels (when at 1x sensitivity). This value is shared with the FlickStick Dots Per 360° (in this Action Set). Tuning Tip: temporarily bind a button to the "Turn Camera 360°" action in the Mouse Actions tab to help calibrate the Gyro's real world angles with in-game angles.
ControllerBinding_GyroTo2DConversionStyl: Choose the style of conversion for Gyro rotation to 2D output.
ControllerBinding_GyroDeflectionUseGravi: On: The stick's horizontal output is based on the difference between the starting pose of the controller, and its current roll angle. Off: The stick's horizontal output is based on the roll of the controller compared to Earth's horizon.

On: The stick's vertical output is based on the difference between the starting pose of the controller, and its current pitch angle. Off: The stick's vertical output is based on the pitch of the controller compared to Earth's horizon.
ControllerBinding_GyroDeflectionTiltAngl: When activating the gyro with "Use Relative Roll" off, what should the world pitch center be? 0° = Pointing at the horizon - Y output will be zero when the controller is flat. 90° The Y axis will be zero when the controller is vertical. 15° is ideal for stand alone controllers, while 85° is recommended for handheld.
ControllerBinding_GyroSampleAngleOffsetX: Tilt the Primary Axis (yaw) up and down, around the controller's X-Axis. 0°: Samples from in front of the controller (Equivalent to "Yaw" Mode). 90°: samples from above the controller (Equivalent to "Roll" Mode). 45°: sample from above the controller's local horizon. -45°: sample from below the controller's local horizon. The full 360° range is available for completeness, but 0° through 90° covers most needs.
ControllerBinding_GyroComplementaryAxisC: Tune the complementary axis's contribution to your horizontal output. This is the axis that is perpendicular to your tilted Primary Axis (i.e. "Roll" is the complementary axis to "Yaw").
ControllerBinding_GyroRollContribution_D: Turning the controller like a steering wheel ("Roll") will cause the gyro to output horizontally (as well as turning it in "Yaw"). This setting allows you to tune how much ("Roll") contributes to the horizontal output. Negative values will invert the contribution.
ControllerBinding_RotationGyroOutput_Des: Adjust the 2D output of the gyroscope clockwise/counter clockwise.
ControllerBinding_GyroToJoystickOutputMo: Choose how the Gyro output is mapped to the Joystick. Camera Style: The deflection of the stick related to the rotational speed of the controller. Tilt Style: The deflection of the stick maps directly to the rotation of the controller vs its initial resting point. Each time the Gyro Button is pressed, the current orientation of the controller is used as the new resting point.
ControllerBinding_GyroSpeedAnglePerSecon: The minimum Gyro speed that can be output to the Joystick (in degrees per second). Tip: Leave this at zero and set the in game joystick deadzone to zero (if available) and set your Steam Input joystick deadzone to your preferred value.

Set this to the in game camera's turn rate (degrees per second) when the Joystick is at maximum horizontal deflection. Tip: set the in game joystick aim sensitivity as high as it will go to reduce the issue.
ControllerBinding_GyroEnableAngleCatchUp: When real world gyro rotation exceeds the In-Game Max Turn Rate, Steam Input will sustain the stick output until the angles demanded have been caught up with. Note: This can feel like the joystick is "stuck" at its extreme after large, fast flicks of the controller, so it is always recommended to increase in game joystick sensitivity instead.
ControllerBinding_GyroInvertX_Descriptio: The horizontal output will be inverted after the 3D rotation is converted to a 2D signal.
ControllerBinding_GyroInvertY_Descriptio: The vertical output will be inverted after the 3D rotation is converted to a 2D signal.
ControllerBinding_GyroMomentumEnabled_De: When the gyro is disabled (by the gyro enable button), the gyro will continue to output for a short time. Use friction settings to control how quickly the gyro slows down.
ControllerBinding_GyroMomentumFrictionX_: How quickly the gyro momentum reduces on the horizontal axis.
ControllerBinding_GyroMomentumFrictionY_: How quickly the gyro momentum reduces on the vertical axis. Tip: set this very high if you want momentum to only turn a camera horizontally.
ControllerBinding_GyroDeflectionAngleMax: The minimum and maximum real world angles to map to the joystick. These angles are measured from the gyro's starting orientation. Use the gyro activation button to reset the orientation.
ControllerBinding_GyroDragCenterPoint_De: When exceeding the Maximum Deflection Angle, drag the gyro reference point with the controller's movement. This makes the controller feel more responsive when moving back from an extreme deflection, but will make returning to center less consistent.
ControllerBinding_GyroLockExtents_Descri: Locks joystick output to the maximum joystick deflection angle. Turning this off allows the full joystick output range into the diagonals. Note: the response curve only affects output between the minimum and maximum deflection angles.
ControllerBinding_GyroJoystickOutputMax_: The minimum and maximum output of the joystick. Tip: Increase the minimum output to combat the in-game deadzone (or reduce the in game deadzone if possible). Decrease the maximum output to avoid triggering a game's "Extra Yaw" setting.
ControllerBinding_GyroJoystickPowerCurve: This controls how aggressively the joystick output deflects. 0.1: Extremely Aggressive. 1: Linear. 4: Extremely Relaxed.
ControllerBinding_SensitivityFlickStick: Flick Stick ° to Mouse Pixels (Dots Per 360°)
ControllerBinding_SensitivityFlickStick_: This value is shared with the Gyro To Mouse mode's "Dots Per 360°" (in this Action Set). One full 360° 'Sweep' on the FlickStick will result in %1$spx of horizontal mouse movement. Tuning Tip: temporarily bind a button to the "Turn Camera 360°" action in the Mouse Actions tab to help calibrate the FlickStick's angles with in-game angles.
ControllerBinding_SensitivitySweepFlickS: Multiplier for 'Sweeping' the FlickStick around the outer edge. Tweak this only after you have tweaked Dots Per 360°.
ControllerBinding_InvertFlickStickOutput: Inverts the Flickstick's output, so that Clockwise sweeps move Counter-Clockwise, and vice-versa.
ControllerBinding_SmoothingFlickStick_De: Smoothing helps to remove noise and jitter from the mouse at the cost of responsiveness. Smaller values will result in less filtering, while higher values will be more filtered and smoother.
ControllerBinding_SnapModeFlickStick_Des: Choose which angle the flick-turn snaps to, for more consistent turning. Turn it off completely for unadulterated turns. Or use the Forward Deadzone value to only snap to a tunable front angle.
ControllerBinding_ForwardSnapAngleFlickS: The flick-turn will only occur if it's less than this angle (from forward). Useful if you want to sweep without a flick-turn.
ControllerBinding_SnapSmoothingFlickStic: Flick-Turn smoothing. Higher = Quick/Instant. Lower = Smoothed/Gradual.
ControllerBinding_SweepSmoothingFlickSti: Smooths out the noise from sweeping the stick. Higher = Responsive. Lower = Smoothed.
ControllerBinding_ReleaseDampeningFlickS: When releasing the FlickStick, the stick may bounce off your thumb, causing unintentional sweeping. To mitigate this, we reduce sweep-turning while the stick is moving home. The faster the stick is moving toward home, the more we dampen the sweep. Low Dampening Speed: Stick only has to return slowly to reduce all sweep-turning. High Dampening speed: Stick must return fast to reduce all sweep-turning.
ControllerBinding_InnerDeadzoneFlickStic: Push the stick as far as this threshold to see the flick-turn begin. The flick-turn speed will scale depending on how far it is between Inner and Outer deadzone. Higher-than-normal Inner Deadzone values are recommended because a more accurate initial angle can be calculated than with small ones.
ControllerBinding_AllowFlickOnAwake_Desc: If the stick is past the Inner Deadzon when the current action set is activated, the flick-turn will begin immediately. If this is off, the stick must be moved inside the Inner Deadzone and back out to start the flick-turn.
ControllerBinding_OuterDeadzoneFlickStic: Push the stick this far to get the maximum flick-turn rate.
ControllerBinding_HapticIntensityFlickSt: This sets the intensity of the haptics.
ControllerBinding_HapticIntensityAbsMous: This sets the intensity of the haptics.
Do not use haptics for this mode.
ControllerBinding_GyroRotationalHapticBu: How intense the haptic bumps are when rotating the Gyroscope.
ControllerBinding_GyroHapticBumpsPerAngl: The number of degrees required to trigger a rotational haptic bump.
ControllerBinding_FlickStickRotationalHa: How intense the haptic bumps are when sweeping the FlickStick.
ControllerBinding_FlickStickHapticBumpsP: The number of degrees required to trigger a rotational haptic bump.
ControllerBinding_Friction_Description: Trackball friction determines how quickly the trackball slows to a stop when freely spinning.
ControllerBinding_Friction_Off_Descripti: If off the trackball will have no momentum.  It will act as if trackball mode is disabled.
ControllerBinding_Friction_Low_Descripti: With Low Friction, the trackball will continue to rotate for a long period after being flicked, slowly coming to a stop.
ControllerBinding_Friction_Medium_Descri: With Medium Friction, the trackball will rotate for a period after being flicked, gradually coming to a stop.
ControllerBinding_Friction_High_Descript: With High Friction, the trackball will spin for a short duration, quickly come to a stop after being flicked.
ControllerBinding_Friction_None_Descript: With No Friction, the trackball will spin forever after being flicked without outside intervention.
ControllerBinding_VerticalFriction_Descr: Vertical Friction determines how fast the vertical movement comes to a stop relative to horizontal movement.  At 50% along the slider it is equal, if less than half it will slow less quickly, if more, more quickly.  For games where you control the camera, it is usually desirable to have high vertical friction so flicks are primarily used for spinning the camera along the horizontal axis.
ControllerBinding_VerticalSensitivity_De: Vertical Sensitivity Scale determines how much vertical movement occurs relative to horizontal movement.  At 50% along the slider it is equal, if less than half it vertical movement will be lower than horizontal, while more will increase the ratio to more vertical movement.
ControllerBinding_SmoothingAbsMouse_Desc: Smoothing helps to remove noise and jitter from the mouse.  Smaller values will result in less filtering, while higher values will be more filtered and smoother.
ControllerBinding_Acceleration_Descripti: Acceleration will cause faster movements to cause more mouse movement relative to slow movements for the same space covered on the pad.
ControllerBinding_Acceleration_Off_Descr: With no acceleration movement will be 1:1, with the distance covered on the pad always resulting in the same in-game output regardless of the speed.
ControllerBinding_Acceleration_Low_Descr: With low acceleration movement will be slightly accelerated, with faster movements making in-game output slightly greater at faster speeds for the same distance covered on the physical pad.
ControllerBinding_Acceleration_Medium_De: With medium acceleration movement will be fairly accelerated, with faster movements making in-game output quite a bit greater at faster speeds for the same distance covered on the physical pad.
ControllerBinding_Acceleration_High_Desc: With high acceleration movement will be very accelerated, with faster movements making in-game output extremely high at faster speeds for the same distance covered on the physical pad.
ControllerBinding_AccelerationGyro_Descr: Acceleration will cause faster movements to cause more mouse movement relative to slow movements for the same space covered on the pad.
ControllerBinding_AccelerationGyro_Off_D: With no acceleration movement will be 1:1, with the distance covered on the pad always resulting in the same in-game output regardless of the speed.
ControllerBinding_AccelerationGyro_Low_D: With low acceleration movement will be slightly accelerated, with faster movements making in-game output slightly greater at faster speeds for the same distance covered on the physical pad.
ControllerBinding_AccelerationGyro_Mediu: With medium acceleration movement will be fairly accelerated, with faster movements making in-game output quite a bit greater at faster speeds for the same distance covered on the physical pad.
ControllerBinding_AccelerationGyro_High_: With high acceleration movement will be very accelerated, with faster movements making in-game output extremely high at faster speeds for the same distance covered on the physical pad.
ControllerBinding_Momentum2DScroll_Descr: With Scroll Wheel Mode enabled a swipe will have momentum and fire multiple times. With it disabled the command will fire a single time, resetting when a swipe for a different direction fires
ControllerBinding_Momentum2DScroll_On_De: Swipes will have momentum and fire multiple times
ControllerBinding_Momentum2DScroll_Off_D: Swipe commands will fire a single time, resetting when a swipe for a different direction fires
ControllerBinding_DoubleTap_Description: A button can be sent when double tapping on the pad.  Tapping doesn't not require a full click, just a quick double-tap on the pad.
ControllerBinding_DoubleTapDuration_Desc: Double Tap Duration sets the time required between times to register as a double tap.  Lower values will require a very fast double tap while higher values will allow a long time between taps.
ControllerBinding_DoubleTapBeep_Descript: Double Tap Beep will cause the controller to beep when a double tap is sent.
ControllerBinding_DoubleTapBeep_On_Descr: Double Tap Beep will cause the controller to beep when a double tap is sent.
ControllerBinding_DoubleTapBeep_Off_Desc: Double Tap Beep won't cause the controller to beep when a double tap is sent.
ControllerBinding_MouseTriggerClamp_Desc: The mouse movement can be dampened while the trigger is being pulled.  This can help to correct for accidental movement while pulling the trigger.
ControllerBinding_EdgeSpinRadius_Descrip: The radius for the Edge Spin Speed zone.  The slider can be visualized as extending a radius from the center outward, with fully to the left as always edge spinning and fully right as only the very edge engaging edge spin.
ControllerBinding_EdgeSpinScale_Descript: If set, when outside the Edge Spin Radius on the pad, the mouse will continue to send input at a the specified rate in the specified direction.
ControllerBinding_InvertXMouse_Descripti: If set, moving left on the pad will move the mouse right, while moving right on the pad will move the mouse left.  Note that game settings often have this same setting, so you need to ensure they don't cancel each other out.
ControllerBinding_InvertXMouse_On_Descri: If set, moving left on the pad will move the mouse right, while moving right on the pad will move the mouse left.  Note that game settings often have this same setting, so you need to ensure they don't cancel each other out.
ControllerBinding_InvertXMouse_Off_Descr: The mouse Horizontal axis will act normally, with left movement on the pad corresponding to left movement of the mouse.
ControllerBinding_InvertMouseY_Descripti: If set, moving up on the pad will move the mouse down, while moving down on the pad will move the mouse up.  Note that game settings often have this same setting, so you need to ensure they don't cancel each other out.
ControllerBinding_InvertMouseY_On_Descri: If set, moving up on the pad will move the mouse down, while moving down on the pad will move the mouse up.  Note that game settings often have this same setting, so you need to ensure they don't cancel each other out.
ControllerBinding_InvertMouseY_Off_Descr: The mouse vertical axis will act normally, with up movement on the pad corresponding to up movement of the mouse.
ControllerBinding_MouseMoveThreshold_Des: Some games will aggressively filter out small mouse values which can cause small or slow movements to be lost. This setting will batch up smaller values and wait to send them until they are large enough to be accepted by the game. When tuning the slider try to keep the value as small as possible while preserving movement.
ControllerBinding_GyroYawScaleAbsMouse_D: When using both Yaw and Roll, the amount Yaw contributes from 0-100%.
ControllerBinding_GyroRollScaleAbsMouse_: When using both Yaw and Roll, the amount Roll contributes from 0-100%.
ControllerBinding_GyroButtonInvertAbsMou: The gyro input button behavior can be flipped.  If set to off, gyro will turn off when the button is pressed.
If set, the device's gyro will turn on when the button is pressed.
If set, the device's gyro will turn off when the button is pressed.
If set, the device's gyro will toggle between being enabled or disabled when the button is pressed.
ControllerBinding_GyroButtonDpad_Descrip: The gyro input can be turned on only when a button is pressed.
ControllerBinding_GyroButtonDpad_GyroNon: The gyro input will always be active.
ControllerBinding_GyroButtonDpad_GyroTou: Gyro Enable Button - Right Pad Touch
The gyro input will be on only when the Right Trackpad is being touched.
Gyro Enable Button - Left Pad Touch
The gyro input will be on only when the Left Trackpad is being touched.
Gyro Enable Button - Unified Pad Touch
The gyro input will be on when any part of the Trackpad is being touched.
ControllerBinding_GyroButtonDpad_GyroCli: Gyro Enable Button - Right Pad Click
The gyro input will be on only when the Right Trackpad button is clicked.
Gyro Enable Button - Left Pad Click
The gyro input will be on only when the Left Trackpad button is clicked.
ControllerBinding_GyroButtonDpad_GyroBum: The gyro input will be on only when the Right Bumper button is pressed.
The gyro input will be on only when the Left Bumper button is pressed.
ControllerBinding_GyroButtonDpad_GyroGri: The gyro input will be on only when the Right Grip button is pressed.
The gyro input will be on only when the Left Grip button is pressed.
ControllerBinding_GyroButtonDpad_GyroLef: Gyro Enable Button - Left Trigger Full Pull
The gyro input will be on only when the Left Trigger button is pressed.
ControllerBinding_GyroButtonDpad_GyroRig: Gyro Enable Button - Right Trigger Full Pull
The gyro input will be on only when the Right Trigger button is pressed.
ControllerBinding_GyroButtonDpad_GyroLef: Gyro Enable Button - Left Trigger Soft Pull
The gyro input will be on only when the Left Trigger is barely pulled.
ControllerBinding_GyroButtonDpad_GyroRig: Gyro Enable Button - Right Trigger Soft Pull
The gyro input will be on only when the Right Trigger is barely pulled.
ControllerBinding_GyroButtonDpad_GyroA_D: The gyro input will be on only when the A button is pressed.
ControllerBinding_GyroButtonDpad_GyroB_D: The gyro input will be on only when the B button is pressed.
ControllerBinding_GyroButtonDpad_GyroX_D: The gyro input will be on only when the X button is pressed.
ControllerBinding_GyroButtonDpad_GyroY_D: The gyro input will be on only when the Y button is pressed.
ControllerBinding_GyroButtonDpad_GyroCro: The gyro input will be on only when the Cross button is pressed.
ControllerBinding_GyroButtonDpad_GyroCir: The gyro input will be on only when the Circle button is pressed.
ControllerBinding_GyroButtonDpad_GyroSqu: The gyro input will be on only when the Square button is pressed.
ControllerBinding_GyroButtonDpad_GyroTri: The gyro input will be on only when the Triangle button is pressed.
ControllerBinding_GyroButtonDpad_GyroLSt: Gyro Enable Button - Left Stick Click
The gyro input will be on only when the Left Stick is clicked.
ControllerBinding_GyroButtonDpad_GyroRSt: Gyro Enable Button - Right Stick Click
The gyro input will be on only when the Right Stick is clicked.
ControllerBinding_GyroButtonDpad_GyroCap: Gyro Enable Button - Capture Button Click
The gyro input will be on only when the Capture button is clicked.
ControllerBinding_GyroButtonDpad_GyroRig: The gyro input will be on only when the Right Trigger is clicked.
ControllerBinding_GyroButtonDpad_GyroLef: The gyro input will be on only when the Left Trigger is clicked.
ControllerBinding_GyroButtonDpad_GyroLSt: Gyro Enable Button - Left Stick Touch
The gyro input will be on only when the Left Stick is touched.
ControllerBinding_GyroButtonDpad_GyroRSt: Gyro Enable Button - Right Stick Touch
The gyro input will be on only when the Right Stick is touched.
Gyro Enable Button - Right Stick or Right Pad Touch
The gyro input will be on only when the Right Stick or Right Trackpad is touched.
ControllerBinding_GyroNeutralAngleDpad_D: This is the default position for a Centered joystick.  By changing this setting you can alter the neutral centered position to tilt forward or backward which is comfortable to your playing position.  Note that for uses like a steering wheel, it is recommended to disable the vertical portion entirely and just use the Horizontal Axis, where this angle will not come into play.
ControllerBinding_GyroLockExtentsDpad_De: When set, if the pad is rotated past outer edge, it will lock to that edge.  If not set, it may flip to the opposite side when crossing this outer edge.  If you experience problems with the controller locking up over time, you may want to disable this option.
ControllerBinding_GyroLockExtentsDpad_on: When set, if the pad is rotated past outer deadzone, it will lock to that edge until rotated past 180 degrees.  If not set, it may begin to rotate in the opposite direction as it approaches 180 degrees of rotation.  If you experience problems with the controller locking up over time, disable this option.
ControllerBinding_GyroLockExtentsDpad_of: When set, if the pad is rotated past outer deadzone, it will lock to that edge until rotated past 180 degrees.  If not set, it may begin to rotate in the opposite direction as it approaches 180 degrees of rotation.  If you experience problems with the controller locking up over time, disable this option.
ControllerBinding_GyroAxisAbsMouse_Descr: For controlling the horizontal movement of the mouse, you can use either the yaw or roll of the controller.
ControllerBinding_GyroAxisAbsMouse_Yaw_D: For controlling the horizontal movement of the mouse, use the yaw of the controller.
ControllerBinding_GyroAxisAbsMouse_Roll_: For controlling the horizontal movement of the mouse, use the roll of the controller.
ControllerBinding_GyroAxisAbsMouse_YawAn: For controlling the horizontal movement of the mouse, use the yaw or roll of the controller.
ControllerBinding_GyroButton2DScroll_Des: The gyro input can be turned on only when a button is pressed.

ControllerBinding_GyroAxis2DScroll_Descr: For controlling the horizontal movement of the mouse, you can use either the yaw or roll of the controller.
ControllerBinding_GyroAxis2DScroll_Yaw_D: For controlling the horizontal movement of the mouse, use the yaw of the controller.
ControllerBinding_GyroAxis2DScroll_Roll_: For controlling the horizontal movement of the mouse, use the roll of the controller.
ControllerBinding_MouseTriggerClamp_Trig: Trigger Dampening is enabled for the Right Trigger Soft Pull.  Squeezing the trigger will dampen any mouse movements until a full click is engaged.
Trigger Dampening is enabled for the Left Trigger Soft Pull.  Squeezing the trigger will dampen any mouse movements until a full click is engaged.
Trigger Dampening is enabled for the Both Triggers Soft Pull.  Squeezing either trigger will dampen any mouse movements until a full click is engaged.
Trigger Dampening is enabled for the Right Trigger Soft/Full Pull.  Squeezing the trigger including clicking will dampen any mouse movements until fully released.
Trigger Dampening is enabled for the Left Trigger Soft/Full Pull.  Squeezing the trigger including clicking will dampen any mouse movements until fully released.
Trigger Dampening is enabled for the Both Triggers Soft/Full Pull.  Squeezing either trigger including clicking will dampen any mouse movements until fully released.
ControllerBinding_MouseTriggerClampAmoun: This sets how much the mouse movement should be dampened.  Slide to the right to further stop mouse movement.
ControllerBinding_AbsMouseTouch_Descript: A command can be sent while touching the pad.  If momentum/trackball mode is active, these buttons will be released when it fully decays.  Otherwise, these buttons will be released the moment you stop touching the pad.
ControllerBinding_LeanSensitivityAbsMous: This determines how far the controller must be turned to trigger lean commands.
ControllerBinding_AbsMouseLeanRight_Desc: You can trigger this command when tilting the controller in the axis you aren't using for control.
ControllerBinding_AbsMouseLeanLeft_Descr: You can trigger this command when tilting the controller in the axis you aren't using for control.
ControllerBinding_TrackballMouseJoystick: Trackball mode makes the pad act like a trackball instead of a mouse.  It will have momentum and friction, allowing you to flick it like a trackball.
The mouse will move like a trackball.  It will have momentum and friction and can be flicked like a trackball.
The mouse will move like a normal mouse.  It will have not have momentum or friction.
ControllerBinding_SensitivityMouseJoysti: Sets the sensitivity of this control.  NOTE: Since this mode is sending the game joystick output - the maximum sensitivity will be limited by the game's Gamepad Camera Sensitivity.  For best results, set the in-game Gamepad Camera Sensitivity option as high as possible.
ControllerBinding_RotationMouseJoystick_: Rotation is the horizon line of mouse movement.  Swiping your thumb over the trackpad may result in a slighly canted movement.  You can align this rotation to match your natural movements, so that a quick swipe results in a perfectly horizontal mouse movement.
ControllerBinding_HapticIntensityMouseJo: This sets the intensity of the haptics.
Do not use haptics for this mode.
ControllerBinding_MouseJoystickClick_Des: This command will be performed when you click the pad/stick.
ControllerBinding_MouseJoystickGyroLeft_: This command will be performed when you lean the controller to the left.
ControllerBinding_MouseJoystickGyroRight: This command will be performed when you lean the controller to the right.
ControllerBinding_FrictionMouseJoystick_: Trackball friction determines how quickly the trackball slows to a stop when freely spinning.
If off the trackball will have no momentum.  It will act as if trackball mode is disabled.
With Low Friction, the trackball will continue to rotate for a long period after being flicked, slowly coming to a stop.
With Medium Friction, the trackball will rotate for a period after being flicked, gradually coming to a stop.
With High Friction, the trackball will spin for a short duration, quickly come to a stop after being flicked.
With No Friction, the trackball will spin forever after being flicked without outside intervention.

ControllerBinding_AccelerationMouseJoyst: Acceleration will cause faster movements to cause more mouse movement relative to slow movements for the same space covered on the pad.

ControllerBinding_DoubleTapMouseJoystick: A button can be sent when double tapping on the pad.  Tapping doesn't not require a full click, just a quick double-tap on the pad.
ControllerBinding_DoubleTapDurationMouse: Double Tap Duration sets the time required between times to register as a double tap.  Lower values will require a very fast double tap while higher values will allow a long time between taps.
ControllerBinding_DoubleTapBeepMouseJoys: Double Tap Beep will cause the controller to beep when a double tap is sent.
Double Tap Beep will cause the controller to beep when a double tap is sent.
Double Tap Beep will cause the controller to beep when a double tap is sent.
ControllerBinding_MouseTriggerClampMouse: The mouse movement can be dampened while the trigger is being pulled.  This can help to correct for accidental movement while pulling the trigger.
ControllerBinding_EdgeSpinRadiusMouseJoy: The radius for the Edge Spin Speed zone.  The slider can be visualized as extending a radius from the center outward, with fully to the left as always edge spinning and fully right as only the very edge engaging edge spin.
ControllerBinding_EdgeSpinScaleMouseJoys: If set, when outside the Edge Spin Radius on the pad, the mouse will continue to send input at a the specified rate in the specified direction.
ControllerBinding_OutputJoystickMouseJoy: Signal will be sent out to the chosen joystick.
ControllerBinding_InvertXMouseMouseJoyst: If set, moving left on the pad will move the mouse right, while moving right on the pad will move the mouse left.  Note that game settings often have this same setting, so you need to ensure they don't cancel each other out.

If set, moving left on the pad will move the mouse right, while moving right on the pad will move the mouse left.  Note that game settings often have this same setting, so you need to ensure they don't cancel each other out.
The mouse Horizontal axis will act normally, with left movement on the pad corresponding to left movement of the mouse.
ControllerBinding_InvertMouseYMouseJoyst: If set, moving up on the pad will move the mouse down, while moving down on the pad will move the mouse up.  Note that game settings often have this same setting, so you need to ensure they don't cancel each other out.

If set, moving up on the pad will move the mouse down, while moving down on the pad will move the mouse up.  Note that game settings often have this same setting, so you need to ensure they don't cancel each other out.
The mouse vertical axis will act normally, with up movement on the pad corresponding to up movement of the mouse.
ControllerBinding_MouseMoveThresholdMous: The mouse will accumulate movement until this threshold has been passed and only send at that point.  Intended for applications that exhibit aggressive filtering/clamping of the mouse, which can cause small motions to be lost, but shouldn't generally be required.  Ideally this should be as small of a value while not losing input for small motions.

ControllerBinding_GyroYawScaleMouseJoyst: When using both Yaw and Roll, the amount Yaw contributes from 0-100%.
